JMock2 not quite as nice[1] as the previous framework t=
hat I used, since the
examples on the site seem to have omitted all the cas=
ts that are required.

context.checking(new Expectations() {{
   one (subsc=
riber).receive(message);
}});

But in practice with JMock2, it would seem t=
o be:

context.checking(new Expectations() {{
   ((Subscriber) one (subscri=
ber)).receive(message);
}});

Previously, I would have had something like:
=

subscriber.expects.receive(message).once();

Where subscriber isn't a plai=
n Subscriber reference; it's a reference to a
SubscriberMock generated-clas=
s that implements Subscriber, along with some
additional functionality / fi=
elds.

But then you don't have to worry about generating the mock code when=
 you use
JMock. YMMV, and that's a minor point.

I also like that JMock2 is=
n't invasive, in that we have a lot of JUnit3 test
cases and I don't need t=
o alter the existing inheritance hierarchy. It'll do
for now until I start =
to feel some pain and then see whether any of the
other solutions available=
 can address that particular pinch point for me.

Cheers,

James
